s.text: The date-glitch issue has obvious technical associations; thus there is a strong connection between the term's appearance and its meaning.
The term begins with a labial sound: the "Y" being formed with the lips.
Masters praised Y2K for its superior sound production, noting that the term features an elegant plosive progression, moving from soft (Y) to hard (2) to hardest (K).
Second, it's gratifyingly symmetrical, with the two consonants hugging that number in the middle.
When Y2K is analyzed as poetry, one sees a satisfying alternation of long and short syllables: a diphthong (Y), followed by a monothong (2), and a final, concluding diphthong (K).
But none of that explains why we're not using, say, Y2M--which simply replaces the consonant representing the Greek term for thousand with the one for "mille," its Latin counterpart.
The efficiency of the term is undeniable--"Y" for "year," the number "2," and "K" for "thousand" (from the Greek "kilo")--and it eventually caught on.
Master, who runs a naming company called Master-McNeil (great name!)
"People were calling it Year 2000, CDC [Century Date Change], Faddle [Faulty Date Logic]," Eddy says.
"People were calling it Year 2000, CDC [Century Date Change], Faddle [Faulty Date Logic]," Eddy says.
